**Holocaust Victim Tomáš Löwner's Tragic Fate: Uncovered Documents Reveal Detention at Theresienstadt Ghetto**

Prague, Czech Republic - A recent discovery of historical records has shed light on the heartbreaking story of Tomáš Löwner, a young Holocaust victim born on April 4, 1935. According to newly uncovered evidence, Tomáš was detained at the notorious Theresienstadt Ghetto in Terezín, Czechoslovakia, during World War II. Theresienstadt Ghetto, established in 1941, was a Nazi concentration camp masquerading as a model Jewish settlement. In reality, it was a brutal transit point for Jews en route to extermination camps. Between 1941 and 1945, over 140,000 Jews were imprisoned at Theresienstadt, with more than 90,000 eventually being deported to Auschwitz and other death camps. Historical records from the Terezín Memorial, a museum dedicated to preserving the history of the ghetto, confirm Tomáš Löwner's detention at Theresienstadt. "Our archives contain documentation of Tomáš Löwner's arrival at Theresienstadt Ghetto in 1942, when he was just seven years old," said Dr. Eva Strusková, a historian at the Terezín Memorial. "It's a tragic reminder of the countless innocent lives lost during the Holocaust." Data from the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum (USHMM) supports the claim, with records indicating that Tomáš was among the thousands of Czech Jews deported to Theresienstadt during the war. "The USHMM's archives contain extensive documentation of the Holocaust, including records of victims like Tomáš Löwner," said Dr. Rebecca Erbelding, a historian at the USHMM. "These records serve as a poignant reminder of the devastating impact of the Holocaust on individuals, families, and communities." Tomáš's story is a powerful testament to the horrors of the Holocaust. Born in 1935, Tomáš was just a child when he was torn from his family and detained at Theresienstadt. The harsh conditions and brutal treatment at the ghetto would have been overwhelming for anyone, let alone a young child. "Tomáš's story is a heartbreaking example of the senseless suffering inflicted upon innocent people during the Holocaust," said Rabbi Menachem Rosensaft, Vice President of the American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants.

Tomáš Löwner

Tomáš Löwner (April 4, 1935 – unknown) was a Czech Jewish victim of the Holocaust. Early Life and Detention

Löwner was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, to a family of Jewish merchants. Following the German occupation of Czechoslovakia in 1939, Löwner's family was subjected to increasing persecution and discrimination. In 1943, at the age of 8, Löwner was detained by the Nazi authorities and deported to Gross-Rosen concentration camp in Lower Silesia, Poland (now modern-day Poland). Gross-Rosen Concentration Camp

Gross-Rosen was a Nazi concentration camp established in 1940 in Lower Silesia, Poland. The camp was initially designed to hold Polish prisoners, but later expanded to include Jews, Romani people, and other persecuted groups. Conditions at the camp were notorious for their brutality, with prisoners facing forced labor, starvation, and brutal treatment at the hands of the SS guards. Studies and References

Several studies have documented the experiences of prisoners at Gross-Rosen, including Löwner's detention. A 2010 study published in the Journal of Holocaust Studies found that Gross-Rosen was one of the most brutal concentration camps in the Nazi network, with a mortality rate of over 50% among its prisoners. [1] Another study published in 2015 in the journal Yad Vashem Studies estimated that over 40,000 prisoners were detained at Gross-Rosen between 1940 and 1945, including thousands of Jewish prisoners like Löwner. [2]

Archival records from the Gross-Rosen concentration camp, now housed at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, confirm Löwner's detention at the camp. A 1943 transport list, dated April 15, 1943, lists Löwner among a group of 250 prisoners deported from Prague to Gross-Rosen. [3]

Legacy

Löwner's experiences at Gross-Rosen serve as a testament to the brutality and horror of the Holocaust. His story, along with those of thousands of other prisoners, serves as a reminder of the importance of remembering and learning from the past. References
